title: Using the glossr package with leipzig.js
text: {glossr} package offers useful functions recreate Leipzig glosses R Markdown texts. immediate solution \(LaTeX\) output use {gb4e} library. enough , can still use package automatically print R-chunk, avoiding typos, even generate automatically dataframe examples! chances , PDF enough , also like nice rendering (least rendering) interlinear glosses HTML well. offers challenges, way print different, way reference different, interlinear glosses pain render HTML. took pain packaged don’t need feel . can start using glossr package calling library use_glossr() activate background stuff. Mainly, function informs functions whether using \(LaTeX\) HTML HTML rendering ’ve chosen. Yes choice! default one implementation leipzig.js, awesome neat alignment, small caps morphological annotation explanatory tooltips hovering . However, negative consequence number examples next translation, rather top line, probably can’t manipulate italics first line (haven’t tried, actually). Enter second option, “tooltip”, instead aligning morphological notation, adds tooltip first line words. gives freedom adapt formatting might1 accessible screen readers. pdf output might install {gb4e} library tinytex::tlmgr_install("gb4e").
code: library(glossr) # library(glossr) use_glossr() # options for html: leipzig (default), tooltip #> Setting up the `leipzig` engine.

Hace calor/frío make-3SG-PRS heat/cold-N-‘hot/cold’ label given as_gloss() allows cross-reference example: PDF example (\@ref(-label)), whereas HTML example (@-label). ? gloss("-label") can used inline generate reference either PDF HTML, depending output file: (1) case. many examples, might want keep file, don’t like already. glossr offers small dataset testing, called data(glosses). Assuming table columns matching arguments as_gloss(), can give gloss_df() directly job. table columns need, select right ones print glosses first three rows. Note values “label” column used labels: gloss("feel-icelandic") return (2). Mér er heitt/kalt 1SG.DAT COP.1SG.PRS hot/cold.hot/cold. Hace calor/frío make.3SG.PRS heat/cold..N.hot/cold; literally: makes heat/cold. Ik heb het koud 1SG 3SG COLD.cold; literally: cold.
code: my_gloss <- as_gloss(   original = "Hace calor/frío",   parsed = "make-3SG-PRS heat/cold-N-A",   translation = "'It is hot/cold'",   label = "my-label" ) my_gloss library(magrittr) library(dplyr) # for select() and filter() data(glosses) glosses <- glosses %>%    select(original, parsed, translation, label) glosses #> # A tibble: 5 × 4 #>   original                                              parsed translation label #>   <chr>                                                 <chr>  <chr>       <chr> #> 1 Mér er heitt/kalt                                     "\\te… I am hot/c… feel… #> 2 Hace calor/frío                                       "make… It is hot/… amb-… #> 3 Ik heb het koud                                       "\\te… I am cold;… feel… #> 4 Kotae-nagara otousan to okaasan wa honobonoto atatak… "repl… While repl… hear… #> 5 Ainiku sonna shumi wa nai. title: Using the glossr package with leipzig.js
text: package also offers extensions working PDF output. one hand, gloss_list() allows nest list glosses reference list individual item. work HTML, just keep numbering top level. PDF, given function , can use gloss("jp") reference (@jp), gloss("heartwarming-jp") gloss("languid-jp") reference (5) (6). Kotae-nagara otousan okaasan wa honobonoto atatakai2 mono ni tsutsum-areru kimochi ga shi-ta. reply-father mother TOP heartwarming warm thing surround-PASS feeling NOM -PST replying (question), Father Mohter felt like surrounded something heart warming. Ainiku sonna shumi wa nai. Tsumetai-none. Kedaru-souna koe da-tta. unfortunately interest TOP .exist cold-EMPH languid-seem voice COP-PST Unfortunately never interest. cold. () voice sounded languid. Finally, might case want apply \(LaTeX\) formatting long string elements first lines glosses, e.g. set half example italics. order facilitate applying formatting individual element, package offers gloss_format_words(), can implement strings given as_gloss(). Internally, glossr try parse \(LaTeX\) formatting HTML one (’m assuming data prepared ). future might different. Hace calor/frío make.3SG.PRS heat/cold.N.‘hot/cold’
code: filter(glosses, endsWith(label, "jp")) %>%    gloss_df() %>%    gloss_list(listlabel = "jp") gloss_format_words("A long piece of text", "textit") #> [1] "\\textit{A} \\textit{long} \\textit{piece} \\textit{of} \\textit{text}" my_gloss <- as_gloss(   original = gloss_format_words("Hace calor/frío", "textbf"),   parsed = "make.3SG.PRS heat/cold.N.A",   translation = "'It is hot/cold'",   label = "formatted" ) my_gloss
